data.title: nodejs debug not working - sometimes...
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10
- NodeJS: 4.1.1

Steps to Reproduce:
It happen on one computer sometimes on other never.... I'm not able to reproduce 100% on this one that it happen.

The effect of starting debugging is:
- on top debug panel that disappear after 2-3 seconds, 
- in debug console typical 2 lines:

```
node --debug-brk=36163 --nolazy server.js 
Debugger listening on port 36163
```

I would like to make some more research on this issue. Please give more details how to proceed - may be some docs?

data.title: Move user data to ~/.vscode[-variant]/user-data and automatically set root user data dir

@bpasero let me know what you think

data.title: Error starting OmniSharp
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Kubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install C# extension.
2. Try to edit an existing C# project, already containing a .csproj file in the folder.

[INFO] Starting OmniSharp at '/home/william/Documents/Projects/SQL/SQL.sln'...
[INFO] Started OmniSharp from '/home/william/.vscode/extensions/ms-vscode.csharp-0.3.7/bin/omnisharp' with process id 13156...
System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Framework.Runtime.Loader, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null' or one of its dependencies.
File name: 'Microsoft.Framework.Runtime.Loader, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'
  at dnx.host.RuntimeBootstrapper.ExecuteAsync (System.String[] args) <0x40d53690 + 0x00857> in <filename unknown>:0 
  at dnx.host.RuntimeBootstrapper.Execute (System.String[] args) <0x40d53460 + 0x00063> in <filename unknown>:0 
[ERROR] Error: Failed to start OmniSharp

data.title: IME Composition font is different from the font specified by editor.fontFamily
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.1-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Turn IME on and type some characters.
2. You can see the font during IME composition is different from the font specified by editor.fontFamily.

![animation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311400/14688163/349df892-077c-11e6-9372-a877d4cd197d.gif)

data.title: TypeScript syntax highlighting: improve function expressions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Mac OS X latest

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add the following to a TS file: `const foo = (): Model => ({ 'bar': 'baz' })`

Result: the function body expression has no detail.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/921609/14686724/02f506c2-0732-11e6-8d97-5432dbec081c.png)

This is true for larger expressions too:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/921609/14686734/0bd94320-0732-11e6-92ab-6efdc226942f.png)

data.title: AutoSave when app looses focus
data.body:
When working with automatic rebuild/refresh tools (e.g. in web development) it would be handy if vscode would save all modified files as soon as its window looses the focus when switching to another application.

There is an option `files.autoSave: onFocusChange`. There should be another option `onWindowDeactivation` or something like that.

JetBrains' line of IDEs has this option. IMHO it's very handy.

data.title: Regression: Code fails to tokenize files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.1-insider
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10 on Linux 4.2

Steps to Reproduce:

2. Observe 'The mode has failed while tokenizing the input.' in a message on opening a file.

data.title: C# does not autocomplete closing quotation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.1-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a c# file and start typing a method that accepts a string.
2. Console.WriteLine( Type a " here

Actual:
Does not autocomplete the ending ". This is not the behavior of Visual Studio 2015.

data.title: Use specific user data directories when running as root

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body: Instead of needing to use `--user-data-dir` while running as root, this should be handled before Electron is launched.

data.title: Light themes (and some others) do not recognize all python keywords
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Sample code

```
a = {}
if "a" not in a:
    pass
```

Expected `not` and `in` should be recognized as keywords in all themes, but looks like only imported from Textmate (like monokai) are recognize them as keywords.

![python-themes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/597158/14683226/7573cf7a-06de-11e6-8821-f0655cdc4c22.gif)

data.title: Allow to ignore extensions
Indent Patterns are not defined/work for Python
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create new `.py` file
2. Start typing `def test():`
3. Press enter

Expected:
Code editor should indent function body.

Actual:
Editor keeps old indention

data.title: Alt-F-S doesn't save the current file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. edit a file (VSCode marks it as needing to be saved)
2. Alt+F+S

file doesn't save.  in any other windows program, chording Alt+F (let go of F, keep holding Alt) + S will save the file.  

if you let go of "Alt" between F and S, it works.  my muscle memory is messing with me.

data.title: dotnet run works, but vs code shows lots of errors
data.body:
Hi guys!

I use VS Code to develop my ASPNetCore application. It highlights over 50% of my code as errorous from the beginnging, even if `dotnet run` works just fine. I first thought that it's just a bug that you are aware of and are going to fix in a coming version. But when you guys released V1.0, I began to doubt that.

Also, VS Code constantly tells me that I need to restore, even if I have manually restored using `dotnet restore`. And if I let VS Code do its own restore, I cannot start my application using `dotnet run` anymore until I do `dotnet reload` manually again.

So, is this a bug or am I doing something wrong?

Thanks for your help! :)

data.title: Make pinning of editors configurable
data.body:
There is a desire to configure preview editors via settings:
- allow to always pin an editor when it opens
- allow to always pin a file when it opens from quick open

**Original Post**:
I would expect Ctrl+P opening a new editor (which it does) and then adding that file to working files (which it doesn't). Instead the file is just revealed in the tree view and I have to double click on it to add it.

Surely Ctrl+P should be viewed as a "I mean to edit" action and not "Just a quick glance"? Does anybody else share my view?

data.title: Dark Theme JSX attributes grayed out
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 7, 10

See the screenshot, Dark theme compared to Monokai theme. Only strings are colored inside JSX attributes.

![vscode-jsx-dark-theme-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9638588/14678634/3207fc3e-071f-11e6-8a4f-b74d16d457c4.png)

data.title: Debug exploration: Async Callstacks
data.body: In chrome and node dev tools you enable async callstacks which means calls like setTimeout are not without parent but it shows where setTimeout was invoked when debugging its callback function. Pretty handy

data.title: debug - merge Watch and Variables section
data.body:
When debugging I feel often distracted by the _Watch_ section and I would propose to merge its information with the _Variables_ section. It should be shown as a subgroup similar to scope variables. 

For me, and I believe I am not alone with that, the Variables and the Callstack sections are the most important. Now, my problem is that I actually use the Watch-section and therefore cannot just collapse it. That brings me the problem of managing it's size which effectively means I usually waste a lot of space at the bottom of the Variables and Watches section. I think the experience would be much better if it becomes an auto-sized node the Variables section.

![screen shot 2016-04-20 at 15 44 31](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1794099/14676745/1f3d843a-070f-11e6-9f98-1d496e75395f.png)

data.title: Create new conf files with right indent settings
javascript doc comments don't work for a parameter named `type`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a .js file containing the snippet below
2. hover over the function's name

``` javascript
/**
 * @param {string} type
 */
function test(type) {
    return true;
}
```

the type hint for `type` should be `string`, but instead it is `any`

other parameter names do not suffer from the issue

i made a screenshot for your viewing pleasure:

![type](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18557590/14675729/1b36c49c-0713-11e6-996a-305a3ff64b14.png)

the dev tools console is empty and i don't have any extensions installed

data.body:

data.title: Add a global action to add a new file in the explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.3

I noticed that we can set `workbench.action.files.newFolder` to a keybinding. Which creates a nice input field in the sidebar to create the directory at the current selected position.

![screen shot 2016-04-20 at 15 06 05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1913805/14675479/7f52a86a-0709-11e6-9f55-4253728f5cb5.png)

But there is no possibility to do this for a file. Yes you can bind `workbench.action.files.newUntitledFile` but it does not do the same thing. It just creates a new `untitled file` and when pressing <kbd>cmd</kbd> + <kbd>s</kbd> you have to choose the destination in a picker. 

So, is it possible to add something for a new file as well? It would really improve my speed because I don't have to touch my mouse anymore to create a new named file in a specific directory.

data.title: Regular expression in Find dialog can't cope with backticks
data.body:
![vscode regexerror](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9283914/14674939/bf991772-0706-11e6-8f59-5010c4d29edd.png)
I can't replace text containing backticks. Visual Studio Code doesn't correctly deal with those:
![vscode regex error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9283914/14675320/bc4b680c-0708-11e6-8222-0613fefa850e.gif)

data.title: optimize glob.match for common cases
data.body: Assuming many, many glob patterns look like `**/*.txt` or `{**/*.js,**/*.ts}` it's IMO fair to optimise those `string#endsWith` checks
